importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date of the article's publication, indicating when the public was first informed about Diane Keaton's passing.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Diane Keaton's most prominent film roles were created, including 'Annie Hall,' 'Baby Boom,' and 'First Wives Club,' marking her peak in Hollywood.

keyTakeAways: Diane Keaton, a celebrated Hollywood actress known for her comedic timing and gender-nonconforming fashion style, died at age 79 from bacterial pneumonia.
She won an Academy Award for Best Actress in 1977 for her role in 'Annie Hall' and received multiple Oscar nominations throughout her career.
Keaton was a leading figure in major films such as 'Godfather,' 'Looking for Mr. Goodbar,' 'Reds,' 'Baby Boom,' 'First Wives Club,' 'Marvin’s Room,' and 'Something’s Gotta Give.'

She remained active in film and television well into her 60s and 70s, with appearances in 'The Family Stone,' 'Book Club,' and 'Summer Camp,' and had projects in development including a film with Blake Lively and Richard Gere.
Keaton was a producer and director, notably helming 'Unstrung Heroes' and 'Hanging Up,' and served as an executive producer on 'Maybe I Do' (2023).
She never married, citing her mother’s example as a reason for her lifelong independence and stated that no one had ever asked her to marry them.
Keaton is survived by her two children, Dexter and Duke, whom she adopted in her 50s.
Her death was reported by People magazine and confirmed by producer Dori Rath, with a spokesperson from the Los Angeles Fire Department confirming the medical emergency and transfer to hospital.

namedEntities.name: Diane Keaton
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Hollywood actress and filmmaker, known for her comedic performances, gender-nonconforming fashion, and Oscar-winning role in 'Annie Hall'.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Diane Keaton is the central figure of the article, whose death marks a significant loss in Hollywood’s comedic and dramatic traditions, with stars like Bette Midler, Goldie Hawn, and Steve Martin paying tribute to her unique presence and influence.

namedEntities.name: Annie Hall

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The film is central to Keaton’s legacy, showcasing her comedic and emotional range, and establishing her as a defining figure in 1970s cinema.

namedEntities.name: Godfather
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A film franchise in which Diane Keaton played Kay, wife to Michael Corleone in the original film.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her role in 'The Godfather' series demonstrated her ability to portray complex, emotionally grounded characters, expanding her appeal beyond comedy.

namedEntities.name: First Wives Club
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 1996 comedy in which Keaton starred with Bette Midler and Goldie Hawn.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This film exemplified her success in leading a female-centered, financially successful comedy, signaling a shift in Hollywood’s representation of women in media.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diane Keaton, a celebrated Hollywood actress known for her comedic timing, gender-nonconforming fashion, and Oscar-winning role in 'Annie Hall,' has died at the age of 79 from bacterial pneumonia. A prolific performer across decades, Keaton earned multiple Academy Award nominations and starred in major films including 'Godfather,' 'First Wives Club,' and 'Marvin’s Room,' demonstrating both comedic and dramatic range. She remained active in film and television into her later years, appearing in 'The Family Stone,' 'Book Club,' and 'Summer Camp,' and was also an accomplished producer and director. Never marrying, Keaton championed personal independence, citing her mother’s example as a key influence. The article highlights her cultural significance, with tributes from peers like Bette Midler, Goldie Hawn, and Steve Martin, affirming her status as a unique and enduring figure in American cinema.
title: Diane Keaton, ‘La-Dee-Da’ dame of Hollywood, dead at 79
